instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.5VS0_EN: What is 5VS0_EN? 5VS0_ EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up
threads.message:
Have this board that doesn't power up, found 

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL> - 1.19v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 5.1v

isolated to both <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> to be blow, short between pins 4 and 1,2,3 pins. Resistance reading of about 2ohms. Resistance reading of just pins 1,2,3 to ground is 12ohms, which matches a good board. Replaced both <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> after confirm short was gone on pin4 pad's. Once power is applied, both transistors blow out again. 

Everything else appears to be measure good, except this two transistors. One thing to note, the transistor package label didn't match the new ones i installed which are both 
SISA12DN (new from mouser).

Any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up
threads.message:
"short between pins 4 and 1,2,3 pins"
This is the way how the driver blocks high-side MOSFETs.
I bet there is no short at all.

For some reason, <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>/20 block <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>/20.
And this is done shorting G-S pins, inside the drivers.
The short disappears after some time, or repeated measurments in both directions (diode mode).
I never found a shorted G-S MOSFET with good D-S reading!

CPU power supply doesn't work and should find why.
And fixing <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> problem is the first step.
Check enable signal for <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up
threads.message: Ended up being <CHIP>U8005</CHIP> pulling <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> close to ground resistance. Now fixed. Thanks for the assist.
